docs.title: Lyzer 🏎️📊
docs.text:
A Formula 1 Data Analysis Tool (Work in Progress)

Lyzer is a passion project aimed at bringing Formula 1 enthusiasts closer to the data. While still in its early stages, Lyzer is designed to analyze and compare Formula 1 statistics, providing insights for fans, analysts, and data enthusiasts alike.

docs.title: 🚧 Current Status
docs.text: This project is under active development and is not yet production-ready. Lyzer combines a dedicated C# backend with a React frontend to build a fast and flexible tool for exploring the world of Formula 1 data.

docs.title: 🎯 Features (Planned)
docs.text: Although it's early days, here’s what Lyzer might offer in the future: - Analysis of Formula 1 races, teams, and drivers. - Comparison of statistics across seasons, races, and drivers. - Visualization tools for making sense of the data.

docs.title: 💡 Why Lyzer?
docs.text: "Lyzer" (from analyzer or analyzing) reflects the essence of what we aim to achieve—diving deep into the numbers and uncovering insights for Formula 1 fans.

docs.title: 🌟 Contributing
docs.text: As Lyzer evolves, we welcome ideas, feedback, and contributions from the community. Feel free to open an issue or submit a pull request to help shape the project’s future.

docs.title: 🚀 Future Goals
docs.text: Lyzer is a hobby project with the aspiration of one day going live. While we’re taking it step by step, our goal is to build something useful, engaging, and impactful for the Formula 1 community.

docs.title: Development (Getting Started)
docs.text: Welcome to the Lyzer development environment! This guide will help you set up everything you need to start contributing to the project.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before diving into development, ensure you have the following tools installed:

  • Docker: For containerizing and managing the development environment.
  • Docker Compose: To orchestrate the various containers required for Lyzer.
  • An IDE or Editor: We recommend Visual Studio Code for its Docker and C# support, but feel free to use your preferred editor.

Note: At this stage, only the API is ready for active development. The frontend is not yet in a functional state.

docs.title: Starting the Development Environment
docs.text:
Follow these steps to spin up the development environment:

  1. Clone the Repository Ensure you have the latest version of the Lyzer repository on your local machine: 
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/lyzer.git  
cd lyzer
  1. Start the Containers in Watch Mode Use the following command to start the Docker containers with watch mode enabled:
docker compose watch

The watch command ensures that changes to the API source code automatically trigger a rebuild for the container.

  1. Verify the Environment Once the containers are up, confirm that the API is running by navigating to its swagger docs (e.g., http://localhost:8080/swagger/index.html).

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
• All API code is located in the /Backend directory.
  • Save changes, and the watch mode will rebuild the application automatically.

docs.title: Testing the API
docs.text:
• Use the swagger documentation to test the endpoints
  • Or Use tools like Postman or cURL to test API endpoints.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: • Port Conflicts: Ensure no other services are running on the same ports used by Lyzer.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text: If you encounter issues that you can’t resolve, feel free to open an issue in the GitHub repository or reach out to the project maintainers.
